basics.name: Emma Hogan
basics.label: Ph.D. Student in Computer Science and Engineering
basics.affiliation: Computing Education Lab at UC San Diego

courses: Research Focus: Improving CS Education in Prisons
Undergraduate Thesis: The Role of Technology in Supporting the Needs of All Levels of Incarcerated Students

awards.title: Ford Foundation Predoctoral Fellowship
awards.summary: Award provides funding for three years to support doctoral studies. Recognized for commitment to utilizing diversity as a valuable asset to enricheducational experiences for all students.

awards.title: National Science Foundation BPC-DP Award 2315909 ($300,000 | 2 years)
awards.summary: Aiming to enhance computer science education in prison settings, addressing academic preparation, needs of adult learners, and challenges posed by limited resources.

awards.title: Jacobs School of Engineering Fellowship
awards.awarder: Funding Period: First year of doctoral program
awards.summary: Granted an elevated funding package for the initial year of the doctoral program at UCSD, with additional assurance of funding for the first summer, demonstrating academic merit and commitment to the field of engineering.

awards.title: Computer Science Major Field Award
awards.summary: Awarded to one student in the department for excellence in the field upon graduation

awards.title: Standish Honors Program Scholar
awards.summary: Requirements included an independent research culminating in an honors thesis, 100 hours of community service, and 24 honors credits

projects.name: Improving Computing Education for Incarcerated Students
projects.summary: University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California
highlights: Received Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) grant from NSF
Executing a new research initiative to improve computing education in prisons
Teaching Introductory Programming courses in Fall quarters 2022-2024 at Richard J. Donovan prison, through the UC Irvine LIFTED program

work.name: University of California, Irvine
highlights: Hired as a founding faculty member of the UC Irvine LIFTED program at Richard J Donovan prison, to conduct UC Irvine courses in prison for credit towards a Bachelor's degree
Sole instructor for Introduction to Programming for Sociology during the Fall 2022 and Fall 2023 quarters, and two introductory Statistics courses during Summer 2023
Designed all course materials to be paper-based and offline in order to adapt to the restrictions of a prison setting

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine
